content.question: Dairy farmers are aware there is often a linear relationship between the age, in years, of a dairy cow and the amount of milk produced, in gallons per week. The least-squares regression line produced from a random sample is <math alttext="Milk, hat, equals 40.8 minus negative 1.1, open parenthesis, Age, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>M</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover><mo>=</mo><mn>40.8</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>1.1</mn><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>g</mi><mi>e</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Based on the model, what is the difference in predicted amounts of milk produced between a cow of 5 years and a cow of 10 years?

choices.label: A cow of 5 years is predicted to produce 5.5 fewer gallons per week.
A cow of 5 years is predicted to produce 5.5 more gallons per week.
A cow of 5 years is predicted to produce 1.1 fewer gallons per week.
A cow of 5 years is predicted to produce 1.1 more gallons per week.
A cow of 5 years and a cow of 10 years are both predicted to produce 40.8 gallons per week.

content.answer: A cow of 5 years is predicted to produce 5.5 more gallons per week.

skill.text: Skill 4.B: Interpret statistical calculations and findings to assign meaning or assess a claim.
